hints.content: Start by identifying the first occurrence of the character `ch` in the string `word`. You can use a loop or a built-in function to find the index of `ch`.
Remember that the string is 0-indexed. This means that the first character has an index of 0, and the last character has an index of `word.length - 1`.
If the character `ch` is not found in `word`, you should return `word` as it is. Make sure to handle this case before attempting to reverse any part of the string.
Once you have the index of the first occurrence of `ch`, you can slice the string into two parts: the segment you want to reverse and the rest of the string.
To reverse the segment from index 0 to the found index, you can use slicing and the `[::-1]` syntax in Python, which reverses a string.
After reversing the segment, concatenate it with the remaining part of the string (the part after the index of `ch`).
Consider edge cases, such as when `word` consists of only one character or when `ch` is the first character in `word`. How would your solution handle these scenarios?
Make sure to test your solution with different inputs, including cases where `ch` appears multiple times. You only need to reverse up to the first occurrence.
Think about how you will implement the return statement. You should ensure that the final string is properly formatted and does not contain any unintended spaces or characters.

Your final implementation should look something like this: find the index of `ch`, reverse the substring from 0 to that index, and then combine it with the rest of the string. Remember to return the new string.
